title-group.article-title: A new grape hyacinth from East Anatolia (Turkey) Muscari vanensis (subgenus Botryanthus)

sec.p: A new grape hyacinth from East Anatolia ( Turkey ) Muscari vanensis (subgenus Botryanthus )
TUNA UYSAL1,3* , AHMET AKSOY2,4 , MERYEM BOZKURT1,5 & KUDDİSİ ERTUĞRUL1,6
1 Department of Biology, Science Faculty, Selçuk University, Konya , Turkey
2 Department of Biology, Science Faculty, Akdeniz University, Antalya , Turkey
3 � tuysal@selcuk.edu.tr ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0001-9968-5633

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Muscari vanensis ( Asparagaceae ) is described and illustrated from East Anatolia , Turkey . This species is distributed in slopes of stony rocky areas facing south of Lake Van ( B 5 Van Province ). Muscari vanensis an endemic confined to East Anatolia , is related to mainly with M. botryoides and M. armeniacum . Diagnostic morphological characters have been discussed and compared with those of closely related taxa. At the first glance, the new species is easily separated from its relatives in its dwarf appearance and patent leaves, shorter scape, densely globose-oblong raceme, globose urceolate and swollen fertile flowers. Additionally, karyological, molecular and palynological data were used to support this diagnostic characters and to strengthen the taxonomic background of the new species.
Keywords:Asparagaceae , endemic, karyomorphology, micromorphology, phylogeny, Turkey

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: MuscariMiller (1754: 926) , a genus of Old World origin, displays a broad distribution along the Caucasus, temperate Europe, Africa, and north-western and south-western Asia ( Losinskaya 1935 , Davis & Stuart 1966 , Stuart 1966 , Garbari & Greuter 1970 , Davis & Stuart 1980 , Davis 1984 , Feinbrun 1986 , Rechinger 1990 , Jafari & Maassoumi 2011 , WCSP 2011). Grape hyacinth is a common name to be used for the species within the genus. Muscari is a genus of perennial bulbous plants native to Eurasia that blooms spikes of dense, most commonly blue, purple or violet, urnshaped flowers resembling bunches of grapes in the spring.

Muscari was firstly revised for the Flora of Turkey by Miller ( Davis 1984 ) and it is given to place 20 species from Turkey . After than this revision, some new Muscari taxa had been reported for flora of Turkey ( Karlen 1987 , Tan 1988 ,
Cowley et al. 1994
, Speta 1998 , Güner & Duman 1999 , Yıldırımlı & Selvi 2002 ,
Uysal et al. 2007
, Eker & Koyuncu 2008 , Doğu & Bağcı 2009 ). Followingly, 30 taxa have been ordered in the Checklist of Flora of Turkey ( Eker 2012 ). The number of species for Flora of Turkey is not limited to this list; hence, the number of species has increased to 52 with the last published and new recorded species ( Yıldırımlı 2011 ,
Demirci et al. 2013
, 2014 , Pirhan et al. 2015, Yıldırım 2015 , 2016 , Çilden & Yıldırımlı 2017 ,
Pınar et al. 2018
, Eker 2019a , 2019b ,
Demirci Kayıran et al. 2019
,
Eker et al. 2019
, Doğu & Uysal 2019 , Eroğlu et al. 2019, Eroğlu & Pınar 2019, Yıldırımlı & Kılıç 2019 , Eker et al. 2020, Eker & Armağan 2020 , Eker & Kandemir 2020 , Eker & Yıldırım 2021 , Eker 2021a , 2021b , Uysal et al. 2021-in press).

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p:
The morphology of the specimens was examined using a stereo binocular microscope (Leica EZ4W). For the identification of plant specimens, the basic book titled “Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean Islands ( Davis 1984 ,
Davis et al. 1988
, Özhatay 2000 )” was used. Flora of neighboring countries and regions such as, Europe, Syria , Russia , Palestine , Iraq and Iran were checked ( Post & Dinsmore 1933 , Losinskaya 1968 , Davis & Stuart 1980 , Stuart 1985 , Rechinger 1990 ).

Chromosome counts were performed on somatic metaphases using the squash technique.Fresh primer roots of bulbs were selected and used for the chromosomal counts. First, the samples were placed into 0.002 M 8-hydroxyquinoline at 4 °C for 8 h and then fixed with Carnoy for 24 h at a low temperature. Before staining, they were hydrolyzed with 5 M HCl for 1 h at room temperature, stained with 1% aceto-orcein, and mounted in 45% acetic acid. The slides were mounted in Euparal as a permanent mounting medium using Bowen’s method (1956). At least 10 metaphase plates were examined for each taxon; the best ones were photographed (100×) with a digital camera (Olympus DP-72) mounted on an Olympus BX53 microscope. The chromosome nomenclature was done as proposed by
Levan et al. (1964)
, with the symbols m, sm, and st designating the metacentric, submetacentric, and subtelocentric chromosomes, respectively. Karyotype asymmetry was determined using the mean centromeric indices, the ratio of the shortest/ longest pair, and according to the A1 and A2 indices (Romeo-Zarco 1986). Moreover, the coefficient of variation of the chromosome length (CV CL ), coefficient of variation of the centromeric index (CV CI ), and karyotype asymmetry index (AI) were counted according to the method proposed above (Pazsko 2006).

Taxa belonging to the genus Muscari and a species belonging to the genus HyacinthellaSchur (1856: 227) as an outgroup were collected from different regions of Turkey ( Table 1 ). The leaves of the collected plants were taken into silica gel and dried, and DNA isolation was performed from these samples ( Doyle & Doyle 1987 ,
Soltis et al. 1991
, Cullings 1992 ). Amplification of the ITS and trnL intron regions was performed according to
Garcia-Jacas et al. (2006)
and
Taberlet et al. (1991)
, respectively. ITS1-ITS4 (White et al . 1990) and trnLc -trnFd (
Taberlet et al. 1991
) primers were used for PCR amplifications. The ITS and trnL-F sequences of the Pseudomuscari pallens (M. Bieb.) Garbari (1971: 112) were downloaded from the GeneBank. All sequences obtained were aligned with the Bioedit program (version 7.0.5.3; Hall 1999 ). For the parsimony analysis (combined data ITS and trnL intron), heuristic searches were performed using PAUP software (version 4.0b10; Swofford 2002 ), in addition to tree bisection and reconnection branch swapping, and the character states were categorized as unweighted and unordered. For the bootstrap (BS) analyses ( Felsenstein 1985 ), 1000 heuristic search replicates were used and set at the default settings. Both the retention index (RI) and consistency index (CI) were given for the strict consensus tree, with the exclusion of the uninformative characters. The Bayesian analyses were conducted using random starting trees, which were then run for 20× 104 generations, for 2 independent 4 Metropolis-coupled chain runs. For every 1000 generations that were run, only one was recorded. The run output was examined for convergence, by considering the standard deviation of the split frequencies that were near 0.001. The first 1000 samples (20%) were considered to be burn-in and were removed after they were visually examined with regards to the likelihood score plots. The best-fit model of the DNA evolution was obtained using ModelTest with the Akaike information criterion (AIC). The best-fit model, base frequency, proportion of invariable sites, and gamma distribution shape parameters and substitution rates in the AIC were then entered into MrBayes for the phylogenetic analyses. The stationary of the runs, as well as the convergence between the runs, were examined using Tracer software (version 1.7; Rambaut et al. 2007).

For the SEM analysis, non-acetolysed pollen grains were transferred directly onto aluminium stubs and coated with gold using a sputter-coater. They were photographed with the SEM at the Advanced Technology Research and Application Centre of Selçuk University in Konya . The pollen terminology used was from Pehlivan & Özler (2003) ,
Punt et al. (2007)
and
Halbritter et al. (2018)
. For the SEM observation, 10 mature seeds from each species were dehydrated in an acetone series, critical-point-dried using carbon dioxide, and mounted on stubs using double-sided adhesive tape. The seeds were coated with gold under a ZEISS LS-10 SEM on low-vacuum mode at about 20 nm in thickness to observe their surface structures (Candan et al. 2009). SEM analyses were carried out in the Advanced Technology Search and Application Centre of Selçuk University ( Konya ).

mixed-citation.named-content: A new grape hyacinth from East Anatolia (Turkey) Muscari vanensis (subgenus Botryanthus)

tp:treatment-sec.p: M. vanensis is partly similar to M. botryoides and at less with M. armeniacum , but the former differs in its dwarf appearance and patent leaves, shorter scape, densely globose-oblong raceme, globose urceolate and swollen fertile flowers ( Table 2 ).

Type :— TURKEY . B9 Van : Gevaş , Deveboynu Peninsula , southeastern slopes facing the lake, stony rocky openings, 1750 m , T. Uysal 4261 & A. Aksoy ( Holo .: KNYA )
.

Bulb 15–25 mm long, 15–20 mm wide, without bulblets; outer tunic papery, dark or blackish brown; inner cream or beige and with white dots over, membranous. Leaves (2–)4–5(–8), patent or erect-falcate, linear, 5–16 cm long, 1–4(–6) mm wide, usually longer than scape or rarely equal, canaliculate, apex subacute to acute, upper surface glaucous, outer shiny, without a median line and green and reddish suffused at margins. Scape 1 or 2, 4–8(–12) cm long, sometimes slightly flexuous and pale reddish upwards. Raceme ± ovoid-oblong, dense, rarely globose, 1−2.5 cm long, 0.8−1.5 cm wide in flower, with (10–)20–30(–40) flowers, slightly elongated in fruit. Sterile flowers mostly concolorous, globose or obconic to oblong, 1.2–1.5(–2) mm long, 1–1.4 mm wide; pedicels 0.1–0.5 mm long, white or ice blue. Fertile flowers 10–28, globose-urceolate to swollen ovoid-urceolate, 2.8–3(–3.2) mm long, 1.5–2(–2.2) mm wide, constricted distally, white or whitish lilac, ice blue, sky or pale blue; lobes whitish, minute, slightly recurved and having rarely longitutionally blue midvein in outer; pedicels pendulous, 1–3 mm in flower, 3–4(–5) mm in fruit. Stamens subuniseriate or biseriate, arising the middle of the tube; filaments 0.5–0.8 mm long, anthers 0.5–0.6 mm long, 0.4–0.5 mm wide, blackish purple. Gynoecium 2.3–2.7(–3.2) mm long, ovary 1.3–1.5(–2) mm long, 1.1–1.3(1.6) mm wide, ovoid, trigonous at ventral part, yellow or yellowish-green; style 1–1.2, whitish; stigma capitates and purple. Capsule 3–4 mm long, 4–5 mm wide, obcordate, somewhite compressed, with triangular valves. Seed subglobose, 1–1.2 mm long, 1 mm wide, bright black. Flowering in May.

Eponymy: —The name of the new species was given to the province of Van , which is a city with unique natural and historical beauties in our Eastern Anatolia Region in Turkey . The Turkish name of the new species is Van Sümbülü which name is suggested according to the guidelines of
Menemen et al. (2016)
.

Distribution and ecology: — Muscari vanensis is a local endemic species restricted to the Gevaş district of Van , East Anatolia ( Turkey ). It is a geophyte species of the Irano-Turanian phytogeographical region. It is specific to the calcareous soils (marble recrystallized limestone) at elevations between 1700 and 1750 m . It grows together with Acantholimon caryophyllaceum Boissier
, Aethionema grandiflorum Boissier & Hohenacker
, Alkanna orientalis ( L .) Boissier, Artemisia vulgaris Linnaeus
, Astragalus pinetorum Boissier
, Astragalus zohrabi Bunge
, Astracantha microcephala (Willd.) Podlech
, Atraphaxis billardieri Jaubert & Spach
, Campanula stevenii M. Bieb. subsp. beauverdiana (Fomin) Rech.
f. & Schiman-Czeika, Cruciata laevipes Opiz
, Daphne kurdica (Bornm.) Bornmüller
, Fritillaria minuta Boissier & Noë
, Gagea bulbifera (Pall.) Salisbury
, Galium incanum Sm. subsp. elatius (Boiss.) Ehrendorfer
, Holosteum umbellatum Linnaeus
, Hypericum scabrum Linnaeus
, Juniperus excelsa M. Bieberstein
, Juniperus oxycedrus Linnaeus
, Linum austriacum Linnaeus
, Melica persica Kunth
, Minuartia juniperina ( L .) Maire & Petitmengin, Ononis spinosaL .
subsp. leiosperma (Boiss.) Širjaev
, Polygala anatolica Boissier & Heldreich
, Puschkinia scilloides Adams
, Ranunculus damascenus Boissier & Gaillardot
, Salvia virgata Jacquin
, Stachys lavandulifolia Vahl.

Karyology: —According to our counts, Muscari vanensis has a diploid chromosome number of 2n = 18 and its karyotype formula is 14 m + 2 sm+2 smsat ( Table 3 ). According to Lima De Faria (1980) , the new species has 2 pairs of medium and 7 pairs of small chromosomes in its karyogram and from medium to small ones their chromosomes suddenly minimize and seven pairs small ones get by degrees shorter. (
). According to the indices used herein, it has both symmetric and asymmetric chromosomes ( Table 4 ; AI: 4.19, A1 : 0.24, A2 : 0.36, CV CL : 36.9 and CV CI : 11.37).

sec.title: Molecular and Phylogenetic Analyses
sec.p:
In phylogenetic analyses, twelve taxa from Muscari belonging to flora of Turkey are included as well as an out group species from Hyacinthella . The combined data matrix length (nuclear and maternal introns) are 1255 base-pair and 1073 of them constant. While informative character number for parsimony was 60 and uninformative were 122. The constructed tree by PAUP has trustable tree scores; as desirably, consistency (0.808) and retention index 0.671 are high and homoplasy index was low (0.192). Bayesian analysis was executed with TMV+I model according to chosen AIC criteria. Both analyses and the constricted trees drove the similar topologies and common positions for the examined Muscari taxa. Because of this reason, the analyses were combined and a common tree was constructed. In the constructed and combined tree based on ITS and trnL intron regions, the new species is related to M. botryoides in point of phylogenetic past (PP: 99 / BS: 1) and it take place together with some members of Botryanthus subgenus (PP: 63 / BS: 0.91;
).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this article, M. vanensis , which is presented as a new grape hyacinth for the world, has been characterized and discussed not only based on morphological differences, but also by SEM, karyomorphology, and molecular studies.
FIGURE 9. SEM micrographs of pollen grains in Muscari taxa. M. vanensis (A–B), M. armeniacum (C–D) and M. botryoides (E–F).

FIGURE 10. Tree obtained from Parsimony and Bayesian analysis of combined (ITS and trnL intron) data. The upper value in branches indicates parsimony bootstrap, bottom value Bayesian posterior probabilities.

The basic chromosome number of the Muscari has been reported as x =9. Also, while there are polyploid reports for some species of the genus, the majority are diploid. Chromosome numbers of the studied species in this paper were determined as 2 n = 18 in accordance with the literature ( Stuart 1970 , Karlén 1984 , Dalgıç 1991 , Özhatay & Johnson 1996 , Johnson & Brandham 1997 , Demirci Kayıran & Özhatay 2017 , Bozkurt 2020 ,
Kiran et al. 2020a
, 2020b , Uysal et al. 2021 - in press). The karyotypes of M. armeniacum and M. botryoides species have previously been reported. Different karyotype formulas were reported in five populations of M. armeniacum by Demirci Kayıran & Özhatay (2017) . Then, the karyotype formulas of M. armeniacum and M. botyroides species were reported by
Kiran et al. (2020b)
. Our results largely agree with literatures, apart from some minor exceptions. One of these exceptions is relevant to M. botryoides that a previous report given by
Kıran et al. (2020b)
mentions about a satellite over the short arm of the second chromosome. However, we never determined any satellite in our metaphase plates including M. botryoides samples. Additionally, it is reported that M. armeniacum populations share the same chromosome number but some of them also includes satellites over the a few different chromosome (on the first and second chromosomes). Furthermore, their karyomorphological features show slightly differences. We performed chromosomal studies on 4 different and far from each other population of the two species discussed in above, and we determined that each metaphase chromosome obtained representing the populations was the same number and morphology in a speciesspecific manner. Thus, the morphological differences reported about the karyology of different populations of the same taxon performed by different researchers seem somewhat confusing. The main reason for this is either due to a mistake in the morphological identification of the taxa, or has been attributed to adaptation or speciation to changing habitats for especially a common distributed species. In fact, it has been emphasized that different habitats may have caused morphological and genetic differences. According to Demirci Kayıran & Özhatay (2017) , hybridizations and chromosome alterations are very important for the Muscari taxonomy.

According to the histograms and metaphase appearances of M. pallens , it has been emphasized that the first two chromosome pairs were quite long and subtelocentric. Even, it has also been reported that the first chromosome pair has satellites on the long arms ( Stuart 1966 , Karlen 1987 ). According to our chromosomal work, M. vanensis is clearly different than M. pallens because of its special karyotype. The satellite in M. vanensis is positioned on the short arm of second chromosome instead of the long arm belonging to first chromosome and also the first and second pairs consist of submetacentric chromosomes (
). According to our karyological findings, it is clear that the chromosome morphology of the new species is more related to M. botryoides and M. armeniacum comparison to M. pallens . In the three species with close chromosomal relationship mentioned, the first two pairs of chromosomes are composed of median chromosomes, the remainder of which are small (seven chromosome pairs). It is clear that the chromosomes of M. botryoides are larger comparing to other two taxa. In addition, the centromere index is higher in the new species and this can be commenting that M. vanensis have partly more heterogen karyotype and diverse chromosomes than others ( Table 3 ).

When it was checking the international databases like EuroMED and The plant list, we saw that M. atlanticum Boiss. & Reut. (1852: 114)
is synonym of M. neglectum Gussone ex Tenore (1842: 5) in current. The flowers of M. neglectum are tubular and its color is dark purplish. Additionally, the periant lobes are distinctive white. Therefore, it is clear that the new species is seen too different than M. neglectum in general wiev of flowers. On the other side, the flowers of M. aucheri (Boiss.) Baker (1870: 418) are partly similar to the new species by its having “clear blue and almost globose flowers”. But, the leaves are lanceolate and plus the flower number is too less comparing to the new taxon. Addition to this information, the karyotypes of M. aucheri have been reported as 2 n =18= 12m +4sm+2st and 2 M + 12m +4sm ( Demirci Kayıran & Özhatay 2017 ,
Kiran et al. 2020b
). Therefore, it was concluded that M. vanensis is clearly different than M. aucheri in terms of karyotypes. The synonymed name, M. atlanticum is a synonym for M. neglectum and there is too many chromosomal reports about this lived species. M. neglectum is one of the most variable species via both morphology and karyology in the genus Muscari . According to the data we obtained from previous studies, different ploidy levels (2 n =18, 36, 45, 54 and 72; Stuart 1970 , Dalgıç 1991 , Karlén 1984 , Nersesian 2001 ,
Azizi et al. 2016
, Demirci Kayıran & Özhatay 2017 ) and variable karyotypes ( Karlén 1984 ,
Jafari et al. 2008
,
Azizi et al. 2016
, Demirci Kayıran & Özhatay 2017 ) were reported in M. neglectum . However, the chromosome morphology of the new species are specific to own and it doesn’t to overlapps with the chromosomal morphology and variation seen in the M. neglectum .

There are studies on seed surface ornamentations of species belonging to the genus Muscari (
Tantawy et al. 2004
, Karaismailoğlu 2015 , Karaismailoğlu & Erol 2018 , Eroğlu et al. 2020, Eker 2021a , 2021b ). In the current study, the difference in seed ornamentations is effective in separating the species from each other and is compatible with previous studies (
Tantawy et al. 2004
, Karaismailoğlu 2015 , Karaismailoğlu & Erol 2018 , Eroğlu et al. 2020, Eker 2021a , 2021b ). M. vanensis is clearly different from M. armeniacum (areolate-striate) and M. botryoides (rugose-striate) by its having reticulate and rugose-striate ornamentation. In previous studies based on seed morphology in the Muscari genus, it was emphasized that the members of Muscari could be differentiated from each other in terms of seed shape and seed size (Eroğlu et al. 2020). M. armeniacum is significantly larger in seed size than the other two species. In fact, M. vanensis is a one species with the smallest seeds. As view of outline, the seeds in M. vanensis are subglobose like a baseball and seen clearly different from M. botryoides with broadly ovate seeds. Unlike of the new species, the seeds of M. armeniacum are globose-orbicular (
).

The pollen sizes are larger in M. armeniacum than M. vanensis and M. botryoides .
Indeed, M. botryoides has the smallest pollen grains. The reticulate ornamentation was reported for some species of Muscari ( Pehlivan & Özler 2003 )
and this were consistent with our current study. The muri walls of M. vanensis and M. botyroides are undulate (
) and they have larger lumina than M. armeniacum which has smooth muri walls with smaller lumina. According to our phylogenetic analyzes based on nuclei and chloroplast intron regions, the species thought to be new is related to M . botryoides , M. macbaethianum and M. armeniacum in agreement with our morphological findings. In the phylogenetic tree, M. pallens is taken place in near of M. discolor which is having tubular-campanulate flowers like itself but fairly far from the new taxon and its close relatives. Additionally, M. turcicumUysal, Ertuğrul & Dural (2007: 233) in
Uysal et al. (2007)
and M. vuralii Bağcı & Doğu (2009: 243) in Doğu & Bağcı (2009) , which are morphologically very similar to each other, are located in a separate branch immediately near. An interesting result is that M. pallens , which is currently evaluated in the genus Pseudomuscari , is located alone phylogenetically in a separate clade from the other two species ( M. azureum Fenzl
and M. coeleste Fomin
) of the genus Pseudomuscari . We suggest that M. pallens would be categorized within Muscari genus as a member of Botryanthus .

As a general conclusion, the new species is morphologically unique with its clear colored globose-urceolate flowers, very short pedicels and obcordate fruit ( Table 2 ). Although it shows similarities with M. botryoides and M. armeniacum species with which it is closely related in terms of seed surface and pollen properties, it is separated by rugose-striate ornamentation. In fact, pollen characteristics of all Muscari species
are quite similar (unpublished data), as in the species discussed here. Therefore, it is not possible to characterize the new species as based on only pollen characteristics. According to karyological data, the new species shares the same chromosome number as the species thought to be related or discussed here, but has a unique karyotype; it can be distinguished by the fact that the short arm of the second chromosome pair carries satellites. Finally, molecular phylogenetic studies have shown that the new species has a distant phylogenetic relationship with M. pallens and a closer relationship with M. botryoides and M. armeniacum in accordance with the morphological data. As ultimate contribution, M. vanensis has been comprehensively discussed in line with micromorphological, palynological, karyological and molecular data, compared in detail with the taxa thought to be related; thereby its diagnostical features are revealed, finally presented as a new species for science.

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Campanula stevenii M. Bieb. subsp. beauverdiana (Fomin) Rech.
Galium incanum Sm. subsp. elatius (Boiss.) Ehrendorfer
Muscari armeniacum Leichtlin ex Baker Habit

mixed-citation.named-content: A new grape hyacinth from East Anatolia (Turkey) Muscari vanensis (subgenus Botryanthus)

tp:treatment-sec.p: M. vanensis is partly similar to M. botryoides and at less with M. armeniacum , but the former differs in its dwarf appearance and patent leaves, shorter scape, densely globose-oblong raceme, globose urceolate and swollen fertile flowers ( Table 2 ).

Type :— TURKEY . B9 Van : Gevaş , Deveboynu Peninsula , southeastern slopes facing the lake, stony rocky openings, 1750 m , T. Uysal 4261 & A. Aksoy ( Holo .: KNYA )
.

Bulb 15–25 mm long, 15–20 mm wide, without bulblets; outer tunic papery, dark or blackish brown; inner cream or beige and with white dots over, membranous. Leaves (2–)4–5(–8), patent or erect-falcate, linear, 5–16 cm long, 1–4(–6) mm wide, usually longer than scape or rarely equal, canaliculate, apex subacute to acute, upper surface glaucous, outer shiny, without a median line and green and reddish suffused at margins. Scape 1 or 2, 4–8(–12) cm long, sometimes slightly flexuous and pale reddish upwards. Raceme ± ovoid-oblong, dense, rarely globose, 1−2.5 cm long, 0.8−1.5 cm wide in flower, with (10–)20–30(–40) flowers, slightly elongated in fruit. Sterile flowers mostly concolorous, globose or obconic to oblong, 1.2–1.5(–2) mm long, 1–1.4 mm wide; pedicels 0.1–0.5 mm long, white or ice blue. Fertile flowers 10–28, globose-urceolate to swollen ovoid-urceolate, 2.8–3(–3.2) mm long, 1.5–2(–2.2) mm wide, constricted distally, white or whitish lilac, ice blue, sky or pale blue; lobes whitish, minute, slightly recurved and having rarely longitutionally blue midvein in outer; pedicels pendulous, 1–3 mm in flower, 3–4(–5) mm in fruit. Stamens subuniseriate or biseriate, arising the middle of the tube; filaments 0.5–0.8 mm long, anthers 0.5–0.6 mm long, 0.4–0.5 mm wide, blackish purple. Gynoecium 2.3–2.7(–3.2) mm long, ovary 1.3–1.5(–2) mm long, 1.1–1.3(1.6) mm wide, ovoid, trigonous at ventral part, yellow or yellowish-green; style 1–1.2, whitish; stigma capitates and purple. Capsule 3–4 mm long, 4–5 mm wide, obcordate, somewhite compressed, with triangular valves. Seed subglobose, 1–1.2 mm long, 1 mm wide, bright black. Flowering in May.

Eponymy: —The name of the new species was given to the province of Van , which is a city with unique natural and historical beauties in our Eastern Anatolia Region in Turkey . The Turkish name of the new species is Van Sümbülü which name is suggested according to the guidelines of
Menemen et al. (2016)
.

Distribution and ecology: — Muscari vanensis is a local endemic species restricted to the Gevaş district of Van , East Anatolia ( Turkey ). It is a geophyte species of the Irano-Turanian phytogeographical region. It is specific to the calcareous soils (marble recrystallized limestone) at elevations between 1700 and 1750 m . It grows together with Acantholimon caryophyllaceum Boissier
, Aethionema grandiflorum Boissier & Hohenacker
, Alkanna orientalis ( L .) Boissier, Artemisia vulgaris Linnaeus
, Astragalus pinetorum Boissier
, Astragalus zohrabi Bunge
, Astracantha microcephala (Willd.) Podlech
, Atraphaxis billardieri Jaubert & Spach
, Campanula stevenii M. Bieb. subsp. beauverdiana (Fomin) Rech.
f. & Schiman-Czeika, Cruciata laevipes Opiz
, Daphne kurdica (Bornm.) Bornmüller
, Fritillaria minuta Boissier & Noë
, Gagea bulbifera (Pall.) Salisbury
, Galium incanum Sm. subsp. elatius (Boiss.) Ehrendorfer
, Holosteum umbellatum Linnaeus
, Hypericum scabrum Linnaeus
, Juniperus excelsa M. Bieberstein
, Juniperus oxycedrus Linnaeus
, Linum austriacum Linnaeus
, Melica persica Kunth
, Minuartia juniperina ( L .) Maire & Petitmengin, Ononis spinosaL .
subsp. leiosperma (Boiss.) Širjaev
, Polygala anatolica Boissier & Heldreich
, Puschkinia scilloides Adams
, Ranunculus damascenus Boissier & Gaillardot
, Salvia virgata Jacquin
, Stachys lavandulifolia Vahl.

Karyology: —According to our counts, Muscari vanensis has a diploid chromosome number of 2n = 18 and its karyotype formula is 14 m + 2 sm+2 smsat ( Table 3 ). According to Lima De Faria (1980) , the new species has 2 pairs of medium and 7 pairs of small chromosomes in its karyogram and from medium to small ones their chromosomes suddenly minimize and seven pairs small ones get by degrees shorter. (
). According to the indices used herein, it has both symmetric and asymmetric chromosomes ( Table 4 ; AI: 4.19, A1 : 0.24, A2 : 0.36, CV CL : 36.9 and CV CI : 11.37).

Muscari pallens (M.B) Fischer. [Type specimen: Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh (E), E00326157], Hyacinthus pallens No
: 8520 [ Syntype : Herbarium Universitatis Mosquensis (MW), MW0591727]. Muscari pallens [Geneva Herbarium—Boissier’s Flora Orientalis (G-BOIS), G00753346, G00753347]
.

, Linum austriacum Linnaeus
, Melica persica Kunth
, Minuartia juniperina ( L .) Maire & Petitmengin, Ononis spinosaL .
subsp. leiosperma (Boiss.) Širjaev
, Polygala anatolica Boissier & Heldreich
, Puschkinia scilloides Adams
, Ranunculus damascenus Boissier & Gaillardot
, Salvia virgata Jacquin
, Stachys lavandulifolia Vahl.

Karyology: —According to our counts, Muscari vanensis has a diploid chromosome number of 2n = 18 and its karyotype formula is 14 m + 2 sm+2 smsat ( Table 3 ). According to Lima De Faria (1980) , the new species has 2 pairs of medium and 7 pairs of small chromosomes in its karyogram and from medium to small ones their chromosomes suddenly minimize and seven pairs small ones get by degrees shorter. (
). According to the indices used herein, it has both symmetric and asymmetric chromosomes ( Table 4 ; AI: 4.19, A1 : 0.24, A2 : 0.36, CV CL : 36.9 and CV CI : 11.37).
